awd_titl_txt: Collaborative research: CIBR: Geomorph - statistical software for shape analysis: Enhancing usability, performance, and methods
awd_abstract_narration:
The analysis of anatomical shapes lies at the heart of much of biological research, and methods for shape analysis have found widespread use in fields as diverse as evolution, forensics, medicine, systematics, biomechanics, anthropology, and many others. This project funds enhancement strategies for developing the pre-eminent software package for shape analysis: geomorph. Geomorph promotes an appreciation of the necessary stages of shape analysis, and an understanding of the mathematical and statistical machinery required to evaluate hypotheses in high-dimensional data. The grant supports continued development of new analytical methods and graphical tools to be implemented in geomorph, which will expand the scope of research questions that scientists can address. New methods will transcend the focus of specific biological disciplines, and will broadly stimulate research in any field where shape analysis is important. Additionally, a new method of multivariate model comparison developed here has the potential to transform how we make scientific inquiry in the age of big data. 

Geomorph is widely used by biologists with over 1,500 authors of 1,000 citations since its 2013 release. This grant will thus impact thousands of biologists who require fast, accurate, and flexible software to accomplish shape analyses for their research. In addition to research software and methods development, the grant will also help train the next generation of scientists through workshops and other activities. Workshops will be taught on several continents to provide maximal impact on the scientific community through these training and educational activities. These courses provide opportunities for scientists to learn and apply geomorph in their own research while seeking guidance directly from the software's developers. The project also supports open-source science by providing the scientific community with access to all software updates via its Github repository. The project will train undergraduates, graduate students, and postdoctoral researchers in research. The PIs will continue to support undergraduate research for underrepresented minorities, through Iowa State's LSAMP and McNair programs (PI Adams), and through the Diversity and Inclusion Council of Chatham University (PI Collyer).

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
Rationale: Understanding how and why organisms differ in their anatomical characteristics has been the subject of biological inquiry for well over a century. To quantify anatomical diversity, researchers use the methods of shape analysis from a field called, geometric morphometrics, which capture the geometry of anatomical structures while simultaneously providing graphical depictions of how shapes differ from one another. Because of their broad utility, morphometric methods have advanced scientific discoveries in a wide range of fields, including biology, paleontology, medicine, forensics, and anthropology. However, using these cutting-edge tools requires fast, accurate, and useable software for implementing the procedures in a way that leverages their strengths. One software package, geomorph, is freely distributed, open-source, and contains the ability to conduct all components of a morphometric analysis. This project was designed to further enhance the utility geomorph, by expanding the computational capabilities of the package while improving usability and flexibility. The goal was to provide additional capabilities within geomorph that serve the needs of its diverse set of users: researchers across a wide range of scientific disciplines. 

Results: Research on this project resulted in the production of 12 software releases and several new computational functions within geomorph, 9 peer-reviewed publications (both empirical and theoretical), 3 conference presentations, and 3 invited talks. Additionally, 5 undergraduate students, 1 graduate student, 1 technician, and 1 postdoctoral researcher were trained on the project, and the PI taught 2 international workshops, which collectively trained 37 scientists from 17 countries.

Specifically, new algorithms were developed that enhanced the computational performance of the underlying support functions in geomorph. This resulted in substantial improvements in speed, efficiency, and memory usage, which enables researchers to investigate patterns in large high-dimensional datasets. Additionally, a comprehensive set of tutorials were developed to guide users through their software experience. These are freely maintained and available to all users of geomorph. 

This project also developed a series of analytical and statistical tools, which were implemented in geomorph to make them accessible to researchers. These include new statistical methods for comparing levels of modularity across biological datasets, methods for evaluating phylogenetic signal, a new phylogenetic ordination approaches, methods for combining landmark configurations for overall shape analysis, methods for evaluating multivariate allometry, and methods for comparing the strength of integration in phenotypic datasets. The PIs also developed analytical theory underlying residual randomization permutation procedures (RRPP); a series of robust statistical approaches which enable hypothesis testing in complex datasets and facilitate the calculation of empirically-derived multivariate effect sizes for comparing patterns across datasets. 

Broader Significance and Scientific Importance: This project provides several analytical advances that have broad application; both in biology, and in other quantitative disciplines. For instance, the analytics underlying RRPP are completely general, and may facilitate analyses of complex datasets in biology, chemistry, psychology, archaeology, and other disciplines with high-dimensional data. Additionally, the development of a multivariate effect size, and our approach for their statistical comparison, provides the multivariate equivalent of effect size comparisons in meta-analysis, and may have equally broad appeal and utility across the sciences. Educational Activities: The project has trained six undergraduates, two graduate students, and one postdoctoral researcher directly. Additionally, 37 scholars from 17 countries were trained through two workshops taught by the PI. Societal impact: Use of geomorph in the biomedical sciences has implications for human health.  Morphometric methods have been used in craniofacial surgery reconstruction, mental disorder diagnoses via MRI and other human health applications.
